Award.AwardTitle: Computer Science meets Anthropology: A novel approach for reconstructing locomotion from fossil human footprints

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bipedal locomotion is a unique and fundamental behavior that has driven and shaped the evolution of the human species. Yet the evolutionary history of human bipedalism remains poorly understood. This project is the first to apply interdisciplinary techniques to understand the evolution of bipedalism. The PI also engages the broader public in this research through ongoing collaborations with the Smithsonian Institution's Human Origins Program. Results of this research, and its implications for understanding the evolution of our species, are presented through regular lectures and participation in educational programs at the museum's Hall of Human Origins. The PI and co-PIs recruit and train research assistants from The George Washington University's Trachtenberg Scholars Program. This program supports the education and training of promising students from the District of Columbia public school system, who typically come from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Consistent efforts are also made to disseminate results to a diverse range of professional audiences in biological anthropology, evolutionary biology, and computer science.

In recent years, discoveries of several sites preserving fossil human footprints have offered an exciting new form of data from which to understand the evolution of bipedalism. However, novel techniques are required to analyze the wealth of information contained within these diverse sources of data. This project is transformative in its experimental approach for linking footprint morphologies to the patterns of locomotion that produced them. Experimental biomechanics will be bridged with techniques for robotic vision, to understand how details of locomotion are recorded by 3-D footprint morphology. Those data are used to develop powerful machine learning algorithms, applying technologies from a rapidly-growing field at the intersection of computer science and statistics, to build detailed reconstructions of locomotion from fossil human footprints. By doing so, this project sheds new light on the evolutionary history of the human species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we set out to develop and apply an interdisciplinary approach to address major anthropological questions surrounding the evolution of human locomotion. We have successfully achieved all of the major goals of this study. More specifically, we developed a new experimental approach that uses biplanar x-ray to visualize, quantify, and analyze in 3-D the biomechanics of the human foot on deformable surfaces. We have also used analytical techniques from machine learning, common in many other fields such as computer science and statistics, and applied them in new ways to anthropological questions. These methods have led to significant advances within and beyond the field of anthropology.

The development of a new technique for using biplanar x-ray to study the external 3-D motions and deformations of the human foot during locomotion represents a significant result on its own. This technique is broadly applicable to other radiological studies of human and non-human animal movement, as it permits the simultaneous imaging of both external and internal anatomy. The development of the technique is significant to a broad range of disciplines, from medicine to engineering to biology.

The studies of fossil human footprints carried out during this project have also generated exciting and important results. Analyses have revealed that a set of c.3.7 Ma tracks from Laetoli, Tanzania, presumably made by a member of the genus Australopithecus, were produced by a fossil human who likely walked with a more flexed limb posture than we do today. This could have had major effects on the energetics of their particular form of bipedalism, which in turn may have had broad impacts on the biology of that fossil human species. Analyses of c.1.5 Ma presumed Homo erectus tracks from Ileret, Kenya revealed gait patterns that were largely similar to what is seen in modern humans, providing the clearest evidence yet of a distinctly human-like bipedal gait in a fossil human species that lived in this area around 1.5 Ma. This suggests that important changes to fossil human locomotion, anatomy, behavior, and/or ecology occurred in the time between 3.7 and 1.5 Ma.

This project also achieved several notable broader impacts. It directly led to the research training of ten students (three graduate, seven undergraduate), seven of whom come from groups historically under-represented in STEM disciplines. The PI and co-PIs provided these students with research training experiences, and have continued to provide support and mentorship to these students as they pursue a variety of career goals in the biological or health sciences. Further, the PI and co-PIs have made consistent efforts to engage the broader public. Results have been, and will continue to be, relayed to public media outlets and communicated through museum forums such that as broad of an audience as possible can engage with this research project.
